review.title: A Bayesian Method Reexamined
review.abstract:
This paper examines the "K2" network scoring metric of Cooper and Herskovits. It shows counterintuitive results from applying this metric to simple networks. One family of noninformative priors is suggested for assigning equal scores to equivalent networks. Another family of noninformative priors is suggested for assigning equal scores to equivalent networks. This paper is based on a series of papers by the researchers of K2-RPS in order to test its hypothesis.


The paper follows the results of the K2-RPS-1 task performed in conjunction with the K2-RPS-1 task in the second half of 2014. The K2-RPS-1 task was administered in conjunction with the K2-RPS-1 task in the second half of 2014. The K2-RPS-1 task was administered in conjunction with the K2-RPS-1 task in the second half of 2014. The K2-RPS-1 task was administered in conjunction with the K2-RPS-1 task in the second half of 2014. The K2-RPS-1 task was administered in conjunction with the K2-RPS-1 task in the second half of 2014.
A number of results from the K2-RPS-1 task can be found in this paper.
Two basic hypotheses are discussed in this paper:
1. The number of noninformative priors is inversely proportional to the number of noninformative priors.
2. The number of noninformative priors is inversely proportional to the number of noninformative priors. 2. The number of noninformative priors is inversely proportional to the number of noninformative priors.
This paper investigates the K2-RPS-1 task and its role in the K2-RPS-1 task.
3. The number of noninformative priors is inversely proportional to the number of noninformative priors.
The K2-RPS-1 task was administered in conjunction with the K2-RPS-1 task in the second half of 2014. The K2-RPS-1 task was administered in conjunction with the K2-RPS-1 task in the second half of 2014.
